subject: Roosevelts executive order was a set back for the spelling reform movement

messageBody:
Robert,

We are looking into the opposite thesis: That by endorsing the list
of simplified spellings, Roosevelt set back the spelling reform
movement in the U.S. at least 40 years.

Roosevelt had a number of political enemies who were always looking
for a decision to attack. The executive order to start using the
simplified spellings was one such decision on which the Congress was
able to rally bi-partisan support against the decision.

As part of the backlash, the major papers printed cartoons and
editorials that attacked the decision. Simplified spelling was
characterized as part of an elite conspiracy funded by Dale
Carnegie.

To some extent this was true, most of the nation's top educators,
college presidents, and learned societies endorsed simplifying the
writing system. The reform as also supported by industrialists who
saw language as a key part of their imperial designs. They wanted
English to be the world language. A simplified writing system would
advance this interest.

I think the attack was more on the way that Roosevelt and the elite
made decisions as much as the content of the decision. Had he taken
6 months to get some Congressional and editorial support, the
outcome might have been different.

Roosevelt himself called the executive order one of his major
political mistakes.

Regards, Steve

--- In Read_Alphabet@y..., Robert McBroom <info@o...> wrote:

> I'd like to point out, your idea is not totally new, since Teddy
> Roosevelt also thought that English spelling was a "damn mess",
and tried to promote spellings such as "nite" and "tuf." But even a
man as bullish and Presidential as he couldn't get these ideas off
the ground.
